To alle cristen saulles haly

lese thame of þere bandes, and lat thame passe

than is gude on god to craue,

Wharfore when the priest þe pax wille kysse,
loke þat þou be sayand this:
Goddes lambe, þat best maye,
Do the synne of þis werlde awaye,
Of vs haue mercy and pite,

For in charite er thre kynde loues,
Þat perfet [MS. profet] pes nedlynges behoues
The firste luf is certanly
To thy lorde souerandly.
Þerfore I praye the, god of myghte,
Þou make me lowe bothe daye and nyghte
Be sikirly set euerilke a dele
Soueranly to luf þe wele;
Þat be thy myghte and gouernynge,
I be euere in thy ȝernynge,
Soueranly þe to paye
In alle þat euere I kan or maye;
And pyrst be, arly and late,
To my degre and myne astate,
Alle gude dedes to fulfille
And to eschewe [alle] þat er ille.
¶ Þe secunde is a priuay luf,
Þat nedfulle is to my behoue,
Whilke loue is propirly
Betwix the saule and þe body.
Þere make þou, gude lorde,
My body and my saulle accorde,
Þat ayther be of oon assente
To saryf the with gude entente,
And lat neuere my body to þat ille,
Þat it may my saulle spylle.

Þat I of þere gude, and thay of myne,

A deuowte mon̄ and religyus,
In hys boke he tellus þus:
þat þou schalt gud tent take,
At þe messe no yangullyng make.
Grete sampul he settus þer to,
Why hit is ful hely to do:
Also he tellus þo manere
How þou schalt þo messe here.
When̄ þe preyst says, or yf he syng,
To hym þou gyf gud herkenyng:
When̄ he preyus in priuyte,
Tyme of preying is þen̄ to þe.
When̄ he oponowt þe boke me kneu hyt
In to englys he turneth hyt.
When̄ þe awter is ałł dyght,
And þe prest is re-wesshut ryght,
þen̄ he takus in bothe is hondus
A chesepułł on̄ þe awter hongus,
And komus a lytul downe,
And dows hyt al a-poune.
Ałł men knelun, bot he stondus
And holdyt vp botħ hys hondus:
þer, or he þe messe be-gynnus,
Wel he makunhyt hym of ałł hys synnus;
To ałł þe folke he schryues hym ȝare
Of ałł hys synnus lesse and mare.
So dos þe clerke a-ȝeyn̄ to hym̄
Schryuet hym þere of ałł hys syn̄,
And askut god for-ȝyfnes,
Or þey be-gynne to here þo messe.
þe prest asoylus hem̄ þer blyue,
lerud and lewd þat wyl hem schryue
And know to god, þat harowd helle,
Wheþur hit be lowde or stylle.
þer fore kneland on̄ þi kneus,
As þou be-syde oþer seus,
Schryue þe þer of ałł þi synnus,
By-gynnand þus as þou bygynnus,
As nexte þis rubrycħ stondus
And þer wyht iountly hald þi hondus;
And, þat hit so may be,
Eke þerto say pater noster and aue,
And or we say þe crede,
Al þe bettur we may spede.
Mony sayn̄ confiteor,
Were als gud say þis þer-for:
I know to god ful of myght,
And to hys modur, mary mayd bryght,
And to ałł halows here,
And to þe fadur gostely,
I haue synnud largely,
In mony synnus sere,
In þowthg, in speche, and in delyte,
In word, in werke, I am to wyte,
And worthy for to blame.
þerfor I pray sent Mari
And ałł þe halows holly,
here in goddus name,
And þe prest to pray for me,
þat god haue mercy and pete,
ffor his mon̄-hedde,
Of my wrecched synfulnes,
And gyf me grace of for-ȝyfnes
Of ałł my mysdede. pater noster Aue and Crede
When̄ þou þus þi crede has done,
Vp-on̄ þi fete stond vp sone,
ffor be this tyme, as I gesse,
þe preyst begynnus þe offys of þe messe,
Or ellus he stondus turnand his boke
At þe sowt awter noke.
Anon̄ so stondande,
Wold I þat þu were seyande:
Lord, for þi godnesse,
Let hym bygynne þo offesse of þe messe.
Grawnt ałł þat hit schałł here,
Of conciens gud and clere.
Lord saue þe preyst þat hit schałł say
ffro ałł temtacion̄ to day,
þat he be clene in dede and þowght,
þat hille spiritus nye hym noght,
þat he fulfylle þe sacramente
Wyt clene hert and gud entente,
ffurst heley to goddus honowre,
þat sufren̄ art of ałł socowre,
And to þi modur, maydon̄ clene,
And to þi halows ałł by-dene;
And to ałł þat herun̄ hit sowle hele,
Helpe, and grace of ałł kynnus wele;
And to ałł þat we haue in mynde,
Syb or fremde or any kynde,
God grawnt hom̄ for þis messe
Of ałł hor synnus for-ȝyfnesse;
And reste and pes þat last-het ay
To cryston̄ sowlus passe and way;
And to vs ałł þi socur sende,
And brynge vs ałł to gud ende.
On Sunday or on̄ holi dayus,
Wheþur-so men̄ syngus or sayus,
Gloria in excelsis in hor messe,
Say þou þen̄ as here wryton̄ is:
Ioy be on-to God in hewon̄,
Wyt ałł kynnus myrthe, þat mon̄ may newon̄
And pees in herthe ałł men̄ to tełł
We loue þe, lorde ałł-myȝthy,
And also we blessun̄ þe bysyly;
We Worschyp þe, as worthy is,
And makun̄ to þe joy more and lasse;
We þonkun̄ þe, lord, of ałł þi grace
ffor þe grete joy þat þou hase,
Howre lord owre god kyng lelly,
Owre god, owre almyȝthy,
Owre lord of hewon̄,
Ihesu criste, comely to newn̄,
Owre lord, lombe of god, neme we þe,
And sun̄ of god, þ[i] fadur fre.
þou þat wastus þe wordus synne,
Haue mercy on̄ vs, more and mynne;
þou þat wastus þo wordus wrake
Owre preyer in þis þou take;
þou þat syttus on̄ þi fadur ryght hande,
With þi mercy helpus here lyuande,
ffor þou art holy, made of name,
But of þi self, lord al onne.
þou art he of wysdam moste,
Ihesu criste wyt holy goste,
Wonnying with þe fadur of heun̄,
In more joy þen̄ mon̄ may neun̄.
Wn̄to þat joy, ihesu, vs kenne
Wyt þe preyere of modur, amen̄.
And when̄ þou hast ałł done,
Knele downe on̄ þi kneus sone;
If þay synge, or þay say,
þi pater noster rehers alway.
When̄ þo decun̄ or þe prest þo gospel rede,
Stonde vp þen̄, and take gud hede,
ffor þen̄ flyttu is his boke
Northe to þe awter noke,
And makud a ✚ on þe lettur
With his þowmb he spedutħ þe bettur,
And secħ a noþur on his face,
ffor he hase nede of goddus grace,
ffor þen̄ a hertly mon schal neun̄
þe blessud wordus of Ihesu of heun̄.
Botħ herersse and redersse
haue muche nede of lerersse,
how þay schul rede and here
þo wordus of goddus lawus dere.
Men̄ auhȝt to haue mycul drede,
When̄ þay schul hit here or hit rede,
And lowe to þat suete,
þat with þe wordus owre bale wolde bete.
But sethun̄ owre mater his vp hereyng
þer-of schal be owre leryng.
Clercus herun̄ on̄ o manere,
But lewed men̄ be-howus anoþer to lere.
At þe begynnyng gud tente þou take,
A large ✚ on̄ þe þou make,
Stonde and say on þis manere,
As þou may see wryton̄ here:
In þe name of þe fadur and þe sonne and þe holy goste,
On stydfast god of myghttus moste,
Be goddus worde welcum to me,
Ay ioy and luf be to the. "Glory be to Thee, O Lord."
Whyl he hyt rede, speke þou noghte,
But þynke on hym̄ þat þe dere bogthe,
Sayande þus in þi mynde,
As þou aftur schal wryton̄ fynde
Ihesu, my lorde, grawnte me grace
Of amendmente myghte and space,
þi worde to kepe, and al þi wylle,
þe gud to chese, and leue þe ylle.
And þat hit so may be,
Eke "Ihesu lord, grawnt hit me."
Rehersse hyt in þi þowghte,
Tyl þe gospełł be don̄ forgete hit noghte.
Sone besyde when̄ hyt is done
þou make a ✚ and kus hyt sone.
Men̄ owght to say þe crede sum tyme,
When̄ men̄ herun̄ hyt, say þou þine.
þis þat folows in englys lettur
I wold þou sayd hyt for þi bettur;
But qwen̄ þay sayn̄, say þou not ellus,
But do as þo boke þe tellus.
Hereto loke þou take gud hede,
ffor here is wrytun̄ þe englys crede
I beleue in god, ful of myȝhte,
þat al has wroghte,
Heun̄ and erthe,
and al of noghte.
And in Ihesu, þat goddus son̄ is,
al holly,
Botħ god and mon̄, endles,
in hym trowe I;
þoro þe mekenes of þe holy gost,
þat was so mylde,
He lyȝhte in to mari maidon̄ chas
to cum a chylde.
Vndur pownse pilate pynnd was he,
vs to saue
Down̄ on þe ✚ and ded he was,
and leyd in his graue.
þo soule of hym wente to helle,
þo sothe to say,
Vp he ros as fel
vp-on̄ þe thryd day;
Vp he ros with his wondus
þoro his pouste;
Now syttus he on his fadur ryȝhte honde
in maieste.
Ȝyt schal he kum vs al to deme
in hys monhedde
Quyk and ded and al þat haue bene
of adam sede.
Wole I trowe in þo holy gost,
and holy kyrke þat is gode;
And so I trow þat howful is
bothe flesche and blode;
And of my synnus for-ȝyfnes,
if I wold a-mende;
Vp-rysynge also of my flesche,
and lyfe with owtun ende.
Aftur þat, faste on honde,

Offur wheþur þe luste,

And lelly ben̄ þe to pay,
Kepe hem̄, lord, fro ałł foly,
And fro ałł synnus for þi mercy;
And gyf grace to laste and lende
In þi seruise to here ende.(1)
In þis worde, þat turnus mony wayus,
Make hyt gud to vs in oure dayus;
þo word is (2) grete & vn̄-stabułł,
Lord, make hit gud & sencybuałł;
þe frutus on̄ þe erthe make plentuus,
As þou sees best, orden̄ for vs;
Suche grace to vs þou sende,
þat at in owre laste ende,
When̄ þis word & we schal seuure,
Bryng vs to þat ioye þat lastny euure.
Loke pater noster þou be seyande,
To þo chales be vp-heuande;

þen tyme is of þe sacrynge,
Than es tyme nere the sakering
A litill bell men use to rynge.—D.
A lytul bełł men vsuþ to rynge.
þen schal þou do reuerensse,
To Ihesu crist owne presensse,
þat may lese alle baful bondus;
Knele & holde vp botħ þi hondus Knele downe & hald up bath handys.—D.
And so þou þo leuacion̄ beholde,
ffor þat is he þat iudas solde
And Sythun̄ schowrgut, on̄ þo rode
ffor mon̄-kynde sched hys blode,
And ded, & rose & went to hewon,
And ȝit schal come to demus ewon̄,
Ilke man̄ aftur þat he hase don̄.
þo same is he þou locus upon̄,
Hyt is þo feythe of holy kyrke:
Who trowe þis not schal sytte wel marke;
ffor-þi I rede with gud entente
þat þou be-holde þe sacramente.
Suche prayer þen̄ schal þou make,
As licus beste to þe þu take.
Dyuerse men̄ preyus sere, Sundyrer men prayers serer.—D.
Ilke mon̄ on̄ his beste manere.
Schort Swylk.—D. prayer schuld be with-owtun drede,
And þere with pater-noster, aue & crede.
If þou of any be vn-purueyde,

I set þe here on̄ þat be seyde.
I set here ane that may be sayd
If thu of ane and be vnpurwayde.—D.
If I make hit for þo bettur,
þou may tełł hit here in lettur:
Lowod be þou, kyng,
And blessud be þou, kyng,
Of ałł þi gyftus gode;
And þonkud be þou kyng,
Ihesu all my Ioyng
þat for me spylt þi blode,
And dede for me vpon̄ þo rode.
þou gyf me grace to synge
þo songe of þi louynge.
When̄ þou hast don̄ al þi crede,
þis schalte þen̄ þou rede,
As nexte is wryton in blac lettur,
fful mycul schal þou fare þo bettur.
Lord as þou kon̄, & as þou wylle,
Haue mercy on̄ me, þat hase don̄ ille,
ffor what-so þou wolt with me do,
I holde me payud to stonde þer-to.
þi mercy, Ihesu, wold I haue,
And I for ferdnes durste hit craue;
But þou byddus aske & haue.
Swete Ihesu, make ałł saue
And gyf me wytte & wysdam ryghte,
To lowe þe, lord, with al my myghte.
When þou hase made þis orison̄,
þen̄ schal þou with deuocion̄
Make þi preyer in þat stede
ffor þi fryndus, þat are dede;
And for ałł sowlus sake
Suche a preyer schal þou make.
Lord, for þi holy grace,
Here owre preyurs in þis place,
Grawnt now, lord, for owre preyere,

þat criston̄ sowlus, þat passud are
Graunt vs lord for oure prayeres
That cristen saules that passed es.—D.
ffro þis lyfe, þat synful is,
þat ilke one haue parte of þi blysse.
ffor hore sowlus I prey derly,
þat I schal prey fore serly, neuen serly.—D.
þat þis masse may be hore mede,
Help & hele to al kynnus drede,
ffadur sowle, & modur sowle, brodur sowle dere
Sustur sowle sybmennus sowlus & oþur sowlus sere,
þat vs gud wold, or vs gud dyd,
Or any kyndnes to vs haue kyd;
And to hom ałł þat byn in purgatory pyne,
þo messe be to hom̄ mede & medicyne.
To ałł cryston sowlus holly
Grawnt þi grace & þi mercy;
ffor-ȝyf hom̄ ałł hore trespas,
Vnloke hor bondus, & let hom̄ passe,
ffro ałł pyne & ałł care,
Into þo ioy lastyng euurmare.
Loce pater-noster þou be preyande
Ay tyl þo tyme þo preyst be seyande

Per omnia secula al on̄ heyghte.
than the prest furt ryght
Says per omnia al on heght
We will saye with heghe steuen
Pater noster gude to neuen.—D.
þen̄ I wold þou stode preyng hyt,
ffor þer he wyl pray with he stewon̄,
Pater-noster to god of hewon̄.
he[r]kon̄ hym with gud wylle,
And whyl he says holde þe stylle,
But vnswere at temtacionem
Or libera nos a malo. amen̄.
Hyt were nede þen̄ þus to kenne,
But qwoso kenneþ not þis is leude men.
When̄ þis is done, sey priuely And sethen thu say it priuely.—D.
On̄ preyer anoþer þerby
Pater-noster & furste in latyne
And syþun̄ in englys as here is wryton̄.
Owre fadur, þat art in hewon̄,
Blessud be þi name to newon̄.
Cum to vs þi kyndome,
In hewon̄ & erthe þi wyl be done.
Owre ilke dayus bred grawnt vs to day,
And owre mysdedus for-ȝyf vs ay,
As we do hom̄ þat to vs trespas,
Ryght so haue mercy vp-on̄ vs,
And lede vs into no fowndyng,
But schyld vs fro ałł wyccud þing.
þen aft þo preyst wyl say,
Stond styłł, & herkun̄ hym al-way.
He seys agnus thryus or he ses, lese.—D.
þo laste word he spekus of pes.
In þo laste pes may þou not be,
If þou be owte of charite,
þen is gud of god to craue,
þat charite þou may haue.
þere qwen̄ þo preyst þo pax wil kusse,
Knele þen̄ down̄ & say þou þus.
Goddus lowmpe, þat best may,
Do þo synnus of þo word away;
On vs haue mercy & pyte,
And grawnt vs pes & charite.
ffor in charite ar thre kynnus lowus,
þat þo perfet pes nedely be-howus.
þo furste loue is certenley
To luf þi lord so wortely.
þere-of I prey god of his myghte
To make me to luf þe, day & nyghte,
Sicurly to sette owur ilke a delle
Souerenly to luf þe welle.
Souerenly þe to pay
In ałł þat ewur I con̄ or may;
And to þe preyste erly & late,
To my degre & myn̄ astate,
Ałł gode dedus to fulfylle,
To eschew þo þat are ylle.
þo secund is a priuey lowe
þat is nedeful to my be-howe,
þo whylke luf is propurly
be-twyx my sowle & my body.
þerfore make þen̄, god lorde,
My body & my sowle on a-corde,
þat eyþur part, be of on̄ a-sente
To serue the with gud entente.
Let my body newur do þat ille,
þat I may newur my sowle spyłł.
þo thryd luf is with-owte dowte,

To luf yche neghtbur ałł abowte,
Þe thirde luf es with-outene
To ilk a neghbur me a-butene.—D.
And of þat luf no þinge sese,
þerfore I pray þe, furste of pes,
þat þou wylt make, as þou may beste,
My hert to be in pes & reste,
And redely to luf ałł maner of men̄,
And my tylmen̄ nomly þen̄,
Neghtburs & seruandus & ilke soget,
ffelows, fryndus, non̄ to for-ȝete,
But luf ilkone, fer & nere,
As my selfe wyt herte clere.
And turne hor hertus so to me,
þat we may fully fryndus be,
And þat I of hor godus, & þei of myne,
Haue ay ioy, with herte fyne.
As I prey for my selfe here,
Grawnte tyl oþur ben̄ þat on̄ þo same manere,
So þat ilke mon̄ luf oþur,

As he were hys owne broþur.
And swylk lufe o-mang vs be
Þat we be wel lufed of þe.
Þat by þis haly sacrament.—D.
Suche luf amungus be,
þat we be wel lowyd of þe,
And be þis holy sacramente,
þat now is here in presente,
And be þo vertu of þo messe,
þat we may haue forȝyfnesse
Of ałł owre gylte, of ałł owre mysse,
And be þi help cum to blysse.
Loke pater-noster þou be seyande,
Whyłł þo preste is receyuande.
When̄ þo preyste has receuyng done,
Opon̄ þi fete þou stonde vp sone.
þen̄ þe clerke flyttuþ his boke
Ageyn̄ to þo sowthe awter noke:
þo preyste turnus to his offys,
And says say.—D. forthe of his seruys.
þer with-owton̄ taryinge
On þis wyse þou be seyinge.
Ihesu my kynge I prey þe
Bowe downe þi nere of pyte,
And here my preyer in þis place.
God lord, for þi holy grace,
ffor me & ałł þat here are
þu vs kepe fro ałł kynnus kare,
þat may be-falle in any way,
In owre dedus to do or say,
Where we ryde, or we be goand,
Lyg or sytte, or we stond;
What soden̄ schamce com̄ vs tylle,
Oþur-weyus þen̄ were owre wylle,
We preyun̄ þis messe stond vs in-stede
Of schryfte & of howsul bred.
And, Ihesu criste, for þi woundus fyue,
Wyssus vs þe wey of ryȝtwes lyue.
When̄ þis is seyd, knele þou downe sone,
Sey pater-noster tyl þe messe be done,
ffor þe messe is not cest,
Or tyme of ite missa est
þen þou heruste ite
Or benedicamus, or requiescant in pace.—D. if þat hit be,
þen is þe messe al done,
But ȝit a preyer þou make sone;
Aftur hyt wyl þou may
In goddus name wynde þi way. ga thi way.—D.
God be þonkud in ałł owre werkus,
God be þonkud of preystus & clerkus,
I þonke god as I con̄,
I þonke god of his godnes,
And namly of þis messe.
Of ałł þo preyurs þat now be preyud,
I pray god þat he be payud.
In mynde of god I here me blesse,
Wyt my belssyng god sende me hys.
In nomine patris et filii et spiritus sancti. Amen.
Pater-noster aue-mary & credo.
God send vs to owre mede. Amen̄.

DIV2.HEAD: TEXT F.

LG.L: man or woman þat wol lere,
A masse deuou[t]ly for to here, Adapted to the practice of smaller churches and chapels in England, where the priest vested before the people.
Gode entent þou ȝeue þereto,
And as þis boke techeth, so þow do,
For hit is wretyn what þou schalt say,
Whane þow schalt rest, whane þou schalt pray
Bothe for þe quyke and for þe dede;
As þow fyndest wryte, so make thy bede.
Whiles the prest maketh hym boune,
Vpon thi knees sette the doune;
And hew vp thyn herte wyt gode entente,
The whiles he doth on his westemente,
To god thu pray on þis manere,
As next thu fyndest wrytyn here.
Now lord god, for thi godenesse, A prayer whilst the priest is vesting;
At the begynnynge of this messe,
Thou graunte to alle that hit schal here,
That in concience thei may be clere;
Lord, thu saue the prest, þat hit schal say, which in the other forms is appointed to be said at the Office.
Fram gret temptacioun this ilke day,
That he be clene in dede and thought,
That yuel spirit noy him nought
To fulfylle this sacrament
With clene herte and gode entent;
First princypaly to thyn honoure,
That souereyn ert and socoure,
And to thy modere, maiden clene,
And to thyne seyntes alle bi-dene,
And alle that hit hereth to here soules helthe,
Thu help hem with thi grace and thi welthe,
And alle that we haue in mynde,
Sib or any frend bi any kynde;
And, lorde, graunt ham for this messe,
Of alle hare synnes forgifnesse,
And rest and pes that lasteth ay,
To cristene soules that beth passyd away;
And bryng us to ioie with-outen ende
And to us alle thi socoure sende. Amen.
Whanne the prest is reuest and begynnes,

Whan he marketh him for his synnes,
When þo prest revestis hym mass to be-gyn
and mekis hym to God for his syn.—A.
When the prest revest mess by-gynnys
and mekes hym to god for hys synnes.—D.
Thanne say thu with him confiteor, MS. confiteore.
Or in englische thus therfore.
I know to god ful of myght,
And to his moder, mayde bright,
And to alle his halwes dere,
In many synnes of diuerse manere,
And to the, fader gostely,
That I haw synned largely.
In thought, in speche, in delite,
In worde, in werke, I am to wite, MS. witte.
And worthi I am to blame,
For falsly I haw take goddys name.
There-fore I pray seynte mari
And alle halwes specialy,
And the preste [to] pray for me,
That god haw merci and pitte
Of mi mysdede þat mochel is,
For his manhode and his godnys,
And of me wreche that synful is,
And ȝew me grace of for-ȝeuenys.

HEADNOTE.P: The prayer, in F. 15-38, is here again inserted for comparison.

LG.L: [Now lord god, for thi godenesse,
At the begynnynge of this messe,
Thou graunte to alle that hit schal here,
That in concience thei may be clere;
Lord, thu saue the prest, þat hit schal say,
Fram gret temptacioun this ilke day,
That he be clene in dede and thought,
That yuel spirit noy him nought
To fulfylle this sacrament
With clene herte and gode entent;
First princypaly to thyn honoure,
That souereyn ert and socoure,
And to thy modere, maiden clene,
And to thyne seyntes alle bi-dene,
And alle that hit hereth to here soules helthe,
Thu help hem with thi grace and thi welthe,
And alle that we haue in mynde,
Sib or any frend bi any kynde;
And, lorde, graunt ham for this messe,
Of alle hare synnes forgifnesse,
And rest and pes that lasteth ay,
To cristene soules that beth passyd away;
And bryng us to ioie with-outen ende
And to us alle thi socoure sende. Amen.]
Whanne confiteor thus is done,
Pater-noster folweth sone.
To the prest herkyn than,
Ȝefe thu ought of the lettre can,
The office, the orison, and the pistil,
And answere him wel with gode wil,
Or on the bok thi-self hit rede, MS. redde.
There-to take thu wel gode hede.
Ȝef thu can noght rede, ne say,
Thi pater-noster reherse alway,
Til the decon or þe prest the gospel rede,
There-to thu take wel gode hede;
And at the begynnynge tent thu take,
A large cros on the thu make,
Seyenge thus in this manere
As thu maist se writen here.
In the name of the fadir, the sone, and þe holigost,
On sothfast god of myghtes most,
Wel-come, lorde, thi worde to me,
As, ihesu, lowynge be to the.
After the gospel whiles he seyth the crede.
The time is nei whit-oute drede
That men schulle profre here offrendes,
Or the prest tak water to his handis.
Offere or lete, whethere thu list;
How thow schalt pray, I wolde thu wist.
As next is wryten, I rede thu say,
On this manere, god to pay. pey.—A. (prey.—Turnbull). pray.—D.
Ihesu, that in bedlem was borne,
And thre kynges come the biforne,
Thei offred gold, mirre, and encense,
And thu forsoke not here presense,
Bot blessede wende.—A. wylled.—D. hem alle thre,
Aȝen thei wente to here contre;
Right so, lorde, offrynge that we offre,
And oure prayeris that we here profere,
Thu take ham, lorde, to thyn lowynge,
And be oure help in alle thynge,
That alle pereiles be fro vs don,
Oure gode desire thu graunt vs son;
Off all oure mis-dedis thu us amende,
And in alle oure nede socour thu vs sende.
Aftir wasschynge, the prest wol lowte
To the auter, and torne him abowte (1);
Thanne he asketh wyth gode steu[e]ne
Al men praeris to god of heuene.
Suche praiere I wolde thu toke
As next folweth in the boke.
The holi gost in the lyght,
And sende his grace vn-to the right,
He ruwele thyn herte and thi spekynge

To godis worschepe and his lowynge. (2)
The haly gast in the lyght
And send hys grace vnto the right.
Rewle thi hert and thi spekyn
To goddes wyrscype an louynge.—D.
God reherse thyn seruyse,
And solempne this sacrifise
For the prest, and for vs alle,
That now ben here, or here be schal,
This masse to here, or worschepe do,
The sacryng to se, or pray there-to;
And for alle, the lyues in godes nam,
That thei haue help fram synne and scham;
And for the soules, that hennes be past,
That thei haw rest that ay schal last.
The prest wil sone, in that plase,
Swythe begynne the preface,
That begynneth with per omnia,
And afterward sursum corda.
Of alle gode thu thanke god than,
And pray also for eche man, And pray alswa for ilk a man.—D.
For eche astat, and eche degre,
So wol the law of cherite;
And therfore begynne this prayere sone,
Whanne the prest hath his preface done.
Lord god,(1) honoured thu be,
With alle myn herte I worschepe the.
I thanke the, lorde, as I wel owe,
Of mi godnesse, that I can wel knowe,
That I haw of the resceyued
Setthe tyme that I was conceyued;
Mi lyfe, my lymes, thu hast me sent,
Mi rigth witte thu hast me lent;
Thu hast kept me of thi grace
Fro many perel in many place;
Alle myn helthe and alle my lyuynge,
Holi haw I of thi gyuynge. Haly I have of thi gyfyng.—D.
Thu bought me dere with thi blode,
And deiede Fore me on the rode:
I haw done, aȝen thi wille,
Synnes diuers, bothe foule and ille,
And ȝut art thu redi of thi godenes
To graunt me ay forȝefnesse.
Of thes godys, and many mo,
I thanke the, lord, and pray also,
And alle mi gult thu me forȝeue,
And be myn help the whiles I leue.
Thu graunt me grace for to enchiwe
To do that thynge, that me schold rywe,
And ȝeue me wil ay wel to worche.
Swet lorde, thenke on the state of holi chirche,
On the pope, bisschopes, and [MS. ad] clerkes, pape, bischopes & clerkes.—D.
That thei be bysi in alle gode werkes;
The kynge, the queene, the qwene—ins. D. the lordes of the londe,
That thei be in wile of gode meyntenande
Here state in in.—D. alle godenes,
And rewele here pepil in rightwisnesse.
Oure sibbe, and oure wel-willynge, & well lyfand.—D.
Frendes, tenauntes, tenundes.—D. and vs seruynge,
Olde men, children, and wymmen, Ald men, childer, and women.—D.
Marchaunte, men of crafte, and tilme[n].
'Riche men, poure, and smale,
I pray to the, god, for hem bi tale,
That thei be kepe specialy
In gode helthe, and life holi;
To alle that ben in wikete lyfe,
In sclandere, miscomfort, or strife,
Sike, in prisone, or vppon the see,
Poure, or exiled this lond, thow thei be,
To alle thes, thu sende socoure,
To þin worschepe, To thi wyrscepe and thine honour.—D. and Here the MS. has to inserted above the line; but it is not wanted.—Mr Skeat. þin honore.
Alle that ben in gode lif to-day,
And clenli leuen vn-to thi pay,
Thu kepe ham, lord, fram alle folie,
And fram alle schame fore thi mercy.
Grace euere-lastynge thu ham sende
In thi seruice to here laste ende.(1)
This worlde, that torneth many wayes,
Be gode to vs in alle oure days;

Wedres
Than es tyme nere the sakering
A litill bell men use to rynge.—D. grete, that ben vnstable,
Lord make ham gode, and sesenable;
The frutes on þe erthe make plenteouse,
As thu seist best, ordeyne for ouse,
Sucche grace to vs, swete god, þu sende,
That [in] oure laste day and laste ende,
Whanne this worlde and we schulle seuere,
Thu brynge vs to ioy that lasteth euere.
Thanne is time ney of sacrynge,
A litil belle he wol to vs rynge.
Thanne is resoune that we do reuerence
To ihesu criste presence,
That may loose of alle balful bondes;
Therefore knelynge, hold vp thyn hondes,(1)
And with inclinacion of thi bodi,
Be-hold the leuacioun reuerently.
Sucche praere there thanne thu make,
As liketh the best for to take.
Sum men [MS. Sumen] maketh here praierys Sundyrer men prayers serer.—D.
In here best manerys,
For Swylk.—D. praieris scholde be thanne wyt-out drede,
And there-with-al þe pater-noster and þe crede.
I sette here oyn that may be sayd,
Thu maist hit chaunge chaunce.—D. for a bettere,
Thow I make hit here in lettere. [MS. mlettere]
Welcome, lord, in fourme of brede,
For me thu tholedest a pyneful dede;
As thu suffredest the coroune of thorne,
Graunt me grace, lorde, I be nought lorne.
Or elles thus in latyn speche,
Thu maist hym pray and be-seche.
Aue ihesu christe. &c. &c.

DIV2.L: Whanne the prest hath the leuacioun made,
He spredeth his handes thanne abrade,

Setthen he dresseth him in þe ferst stede,
He wyll sprede his armes o-brade
Sethen dresse thaim in thaier friste stede.—D.
Thanne is tyme to pray for the dede;
For alle cristene sowles sake
Suche praere I rede thu take.
Gode lord, for thyn holi grace,
Thu here oure praierys in this place.
Graunt vs, lord, for this praiere,

That cristene sowles that passeth the aiere
Graunt vs lord for oure prayeres
That cristen saules that passed es.—D.
Fro this lif, that synful is,
That eche of hem haw part of þis messe;
And fore here soules I pray inwardli,
That I schal neuene dyuersli, neuen serly.—D.
That this messe be hem to mede,
Socoure, and help, in al here nede;
Fadir and modire, and brothere sowles so dere,
Soster and sibbe men, and othere ifere,
That vs gode wolde, or vs gode do,
Or any kyndenesse to vs haw ido,
And to alle tho, þat in purgatori haue payne,
Lord, this messe be mede and medecyne.
And to alle cristene sowles holi,
Swet lord, thu graunt thi mercy,
For-ȝew hem alle here trespasse,
Lowse here bondes, and lete ham passe
Fram alle paynes to heuuene blis,

With angeles to dwelle euere endeles.
than the prest furt ryght
Says per omnia al on heght
We will saye with heghe steuen
Pater noster gude to neuen.—D.
Thanne the prest seith with hie steu[e]ne
The pater-noster to god of heuene,
Herkene him with gode wile,
And answere him, loude or sti[l]le;
And sethen thu sey hit pryueli, And sethen thu say it priuely.—D.
For beter praeiere may thu non sey.
Efte-sone the prest wol somwhat say,
Be redi and answere him alway,
Herkyn hym how he speketh of pes,
And says agnus thries or he ses. lese.—D.
Bot in that pes may thu nogth be,
Ȝef thu be out of cherite;
Therefore of god I rede thu craue,
That thu charite of hym may haue.
Therfore þe prest whanne þe pax schal kysse,
Loke that þu be seiende this.
Godes lombe, that best may,
Do the synne of þis worlde away,
On vs thu haue mercy and pité,
And graunt vs pes and charité.
Sut Sic in MS. Read Suth = since.—Mr Skeat. in charité beth thre manere of loues,
That to parfite pes be-houes;
The first loue [MS. pes] is certeynly,
To lowe thi lord souereynly;
Therefore I pray god, ful of myght,
To make me loue, bothe day and nyght,
Sikerliche þe, lord, eueridel
Souereynli to low wel,
That bi thi myght and thi gouernynge,
That I be euere at thyn ȝernynge,
Souerenli the to pay,
In alle that euere I can and may;
And redi be, erli and late,
To myn degre and myn estate,
And gode dedes al to fulfille,
And to enchewe alle that ben ille.
The secunde is priue loue,
That nedeful is to mi be-houe,
The whiche is properli
Bitwixe mi soule and my bodi;
Therfore make thu, gode lord,
Mi bodi and soule of on acord,
That eythere parte, by on asent,
Serue the, lord, whit alle entent;
And late neuere my bodi to do þat ille
That by any way may my soule spille.
The thred loue is with-oute doute,

To low eche cristen man aboute,
Þe thirde luf es with-outene
To ilk a neghbur me a-butene.—D.
And of þat loue neuere ces;
Therefore I pray the, prince of pes,
That thu wilt make, as þu may best,
Myn herte to loue in pes and rest,
And redi to loue alle manere of men,
And speciali myne kynnesmen,
Neighbores, seruantes, and subiectes,
Frendes and foes, and for-ȝectes,
To loue echon, fere and nere,
As my-self with hert[e] clere;
And turne here hertes so to me,
That we fulli frendes be,
That I of here wel-fare, and þey of myne,
Haw cherité with herte fyne.
Right as I pray for my-self here,
I pray the, graunt to othere þe same manere,
That eche man loue wel othere,

As eche of vs were otheres brothere.
And swylk lufe o-mang vs be
Þat we be wel lufed of þe.
Þat by þis haly sacrament.—D.
Suche loue, lord, among vs be,
That we be loued of the,
That therwe the vertu of the messe
Thu graunte vs, lord, for-ȝewnesse
Of alle oure gylt and alle oure mysse,
And thorw thyn help [we] come to blysse.
Whanne the prest hath the rensynge don,
He wol make an ende son;
He seith say.—D. forth of his offis,
Sithe he maketh ende of his seruis.
There-to ȝew thu gode herkenynge,
Lowde or stil ay answerynge,
For the masse is noght cest,
Or the tyme of ite, missa est.
Bot whanne the prest seith ite,
Or benedicamus, or requiescant in pace.—D. wether hit be,
Thanne is the masse alle do;
But ȝet this praiere thu say also,
And aftir for sothe wel þu may,
In godis name, go hom thi way. ga thi way.—D.
God be thanked of alle his werkes,
And thankede of prestes and clerkys;
God be thankede of eche man,
I thanke my lord, as hertly as I can;
I thanke him hertli of his kyndenesse,
And nameli now of this holi messe;
Of alle the praierys that here ben praied,
I pray my swete lord that he be paied.
In mynde of god I me blesse,
With my blessynge god sende me his.
How thu at the masse thi tyme schal spende,
I haw tolde now wel to þe ende.
The ribrusch [Sic in MS.] I rede thu loke somdel,
The praierys þu record with-oute boke wel;

For [of] alle that in this world is,

I pray him of his benisoun,

We sall make a speciall' prayer unto god all' myghty'. and to þe glorius uirgin his moder ouer lady sante mary. and to al þe fare felichyp of heuen. ffor for the whole state of Christ's church, alle þe state and þe stabilite of all' haly kirke. specially for our haly fader þe pope of rome. and for alle hys trewe cardinals. for þe patriark of ierusalem. and spe∣cially for þe haly crose. þat god was done opon. þat god and the recovery of the Holy Cross. for hys mercy. bringe itt oute of hethen men handes. into cristen menes kepyng.

¶ Also we sall pray specially for our haly fader þe For the arch∣bishop, bishop, and all "re∣ligious." archbyschop of þis See. and for alle other archbischopes & byschopes ande for all maner of men and women of relygion. þat god gyfe þame grace perseverance in onest and clene relygyon kepinge.

¶ We sall pray specially. for þe person or for þe For the curate and all pastors; vikar of þis kirke þat hase ȝoure saules for to kepe. and for alle þase þat cure has tane of cristenmen saules. þat god gyf þame grace so well for to teche þare sugettis ilke curet in his degre. ande þe sugettes so weill to
wyrke efter heylfull teching þat bothe þe techers and þe sugettes may com [to] þe blys þat aye sall last.

¶ We sall pray specially for all prestes & clerkes and other clergy of all orders. þat redis or singes. in þis kirke or in any other and for all other thurgh whame goddes servys es maintened or uphalden

¶ We sal prey specially for oure kynge and þe For the King, Royal Family, Lords, Commons, and Council. queyn and all' þe kynges childer and for þe peris and þe lordes and þe gode communers of þe lande. and specially for all þas þat hafes. þe gude counsale of þe lande for to kepe þat god gef þame grase swilk coun∣selle to take & orden and for to do þare efter þat itt may be louyng to god allmyghty. profet and weillfare to þe rem and schame and senchyp to ouer enmyse. gaynstanding and restrenyng of þare power & þare males.

¶ We sall pray especially for þe meer[,] þe xij[,] For the mayor and corporation of York. þe schirriues and þe xxiiij. and for all gode communers of þis cite. and for þame þat has þis cite for to govern. þat god gife þame grace so weil to rewle itt þat may be to god louyng & sauing to þe Citè [Cité sic in MS.] and profet & help to þe communers.

¶ We sall pray specially for all oure gode parechens For fellow-parish∣ioners that travel by land or water. whare so euer þai be. on land or on water. þat god almyghty saue þame fra all maner of parels & bring þam whar þai walde be inquart [Read in quart] & heill both of body & of saule.

¶ We sall pray specially for all þase þat lely and For those that duly pay tithe; and amendment to defaulters. trewly pays þer tendes & þer offerandes to god & to haly kirke. þat god do þame meid in þe blise of heuen. and þai þat dose noght so. þat god brynge þame sone till amendment.

¶ We sall pray also for all trewe pilgrams & palm∣ers For pilgrims and benefit of their pilgrimage. whare so euer þai be on lande or on water. þat god of his gudenes graunt þame parte of our gode prayers & us of þare gode gates.

¶ Allso we sall pray specially for all lande tyllande For prosperity to husbandmen, and safety to sea∣faring people. þat god for his godenes and his he grace and thurgh our gude prayers. maynteyn þame so. þat þai may be upstandand. and for all þe see farand þat god all∣myghtty saue þame fra all maner of parels & brynge þame and þer gudes in quart whare þaie walde be.

Deprecemur deum Prayers are bidden patrem omnipotentem pro stabilitate sancte matris ecclesie et pro pace terre. ¶ we shall make a specyall prayer unto god almighty: And to the gloryous virgyn his moder our Lady saynt mary: and to all the glory∣ous company of heven. DIV2.HEAD: Here sueþ a preciouse mater. how a man schal make hym cleer and perfite clene bifore þe resseyuynge of þe sacramente of þe auter.
DIV2.P: BIfore þe resceyuynge of cristis body syxe þingis þer Six consider∣ations before communicating. ben to concidere.

¶ The firste is þat a man knowe by vertu of dis∣cressioun. what he schal resceyue. and what he is þat What he receives. resseyueþ it. ¶ Lo! lo! what schal he resceyue? soþely ihesu crist—sooþfaste god and man, þat made alle þing of nouȝtte, And sooþfaste man þat dyed for vs on þe crosse—in forme of breed. what is he þat re∣sceyueþ What he is. it? soþely a man and no beeste, ne feende, þer∣fore alle feendis malice. and alle beestelynesse of synne he owiþ to caste [fol. 223 b.] from hym.

¶ þe secunde is deuocioun of herte; for he schal He must receive with devotion, concidere, þat whom he resseyueþ he shal resseyue it in as myche holinesse as he may: and loke he þat he here-wiþ putte awey from hym bittirnesse and blynde∣nesse a softened heart and diligent prayer, of herte, wiþ compassioun of teeris and þorouȝ besynesse of preyers.

¶ þe þridde is wiþ reuerence of herte. þat suche a with reverence at drawing near to One so great, vyle creature and a wrecchid synner be aferde to neiȝ hem suche a lord; For if a man were dipped alle in stynke, vnworþi he were to stonde in presence of þe kyng ¶ I preye þee þenne—how myche more vnworþi when so un∣worthy, is eny man, as of hym silf, for to resceyue crist in þe preciouse sacramente. For whi alle oure good deedis. ben as vnclennesse in his siȝtte, what ben oure synnes þenne? trewely nouȝt. ¶ But not wiþstandande alle
þat, his goodnesse and his pitee is more þenne al oure but trusting in his mercy, we come to him, and he will enable us to serve him truly. wrecchidnesse; and þer-fore do we þat is in vs. and in triste of hym wiþ reuerente drede goo we to hym, For whi his worþinesse schal maken vs worþi to do hym seruise.

¶ þe fourþe is loue and desyre of herte. wherfore a With a loving and glad heart, man owiþ to be war þat he go not to þis sacramente rechelesly, ne wiþ heuinesse, ne wiþ irkynge of herte, but loke he do it deuoutely and gladdely. and wiþ greet desyre, wherfore it semiþ myche wondir to me þat euery man in resceyuynge of þis worþi sacramente meltiþ [not] al in-to loue.

¶ þe conciderynge of cristis passyoun and of his which is most of all moved by con∣sidering Christ's love in dying for us. loue vn-to vs is souereyne meene to steere a mannes affeccioun to deuoute resceyuyng of þis hooly and blessydful sacramente.

¶ The fyȝfte is a meke deuoute preyere. For whi for With devout prayer for pardon and grace. þat encheson amonge oþur was þe sacramente ordeyned. so þat a man þorouȝ offrynge and takynge of it schulde aske forȝeuenesse of synnes [fol. 224] and grace of good lijf.

¶ sixte is þat he be a preste þat schulde mynistre Considerations if he be the priest that has to ad∣minister this sacrament. þis sacramente. so þat he do alle his diligence aboute it. in þat, þat in him is. ¶ For siþen a man is besy. to serue an eerþely man. or a lord wiþ al his diligence abouten hym, miche more schulde he ben besy. for to serue to oure lord god. ¶ And þerfore alle maner of men of moste honeste. and of sobrenesse. and of good continuaunce. and here-wiþ to ben wel avysed. is þenne moste nedeful to ministre þis moste worschipeful sacra∣mente He should abstain from things of this world, ¶ And so þat a preeste may þe bettir do þis worþi ocupacioun. I counceyle hym þat he absteyne hym from alle þingis tymely þat myȝtte fylen his soule þat is þe wonyinge of crist. þe heuenly kyng. so þat he may bere Read ben.—Compare ben, l. 25. myche more stiffeloker groundyd in goddis seruise. ȝe, ȝe, myche more þenne eny oþur seculer man.
and namely þenne whenne he schal go to masse. þat he and especially when going to mass. hym redily speede.

¶ The seuenþe is þat he wiþdrawe his mynde from A man must with∣draw into him∣self, alle outward þingis. and gadre hym silf al hool in-to hym silf, if he may, so enteerly. þat neiþir he be scatered by bodily witte ne wiþ veyneglorie. ¶ And þenne ransake his owne concience. and þat þat he and search and examine his own conscience, fyndeþ vncleene. loke þat he wasche hem awey wiþ teeris of conpunccioun. þenne bihoueþ him go to his and go to con∣fession. confessoure. and caste out wiþ meke schrifte alle venym of synne.

¶ And whenne he haþ doon þus. þenne muste hym In all humility he must think of the meekness of God lifte vp his herte wiþ alle maner of þe moste humilite. and concidere þe mekenesse of god. and þe wrecchid freyelte of his owne fleische. ¶ How myche and how and his own frailty; worþi þat god is and how litle and how vnworþi hym silf is / and þus schal he of hym silf make nouȝtte and magnifye god. þat he [fol. 224 b.] may be turned in-to god. so þat he se noon oþur þing. ne feele but god ¶ þenne if he suffre þus mekely and pacientely. in alle tymes. he may myche þe liȝtteloker. and þe more suloker þenke on þe greet loue of oure lord ihesu crist. þat wolde of hym of the great love of our Lord; silf þat is so worþi ȝeue his lijf to distroye þe syneful lijf of mankynde ¶ þenne may he wel þenke vp-on þe poyntis of cristis passioun. and ouere þat for to wondre. of his wondirful charite. þat not oonly wolde offre hym in dying for us, and offering him∣self to us in this sacrament. silf to vs on þe crosse. but he offriþ hym silf to vs in þe sacramente of þe auter for to be fully with vs ¶ Ȝe ȝe and ȝit þerto ful myche more. for he ȝeueþ hym silf to vs. for to be ful surely groundyd in oure hertis. ¶ A! good and graciouse swete lord. who may suffyse for to þenke þe leste sparkele of þi wondirful sweete loue—soþely no man.

¶ þerfore byfore þe resseyuynge of þis worþi and Devotion for a priest before receiving; moste hooly sacramente. a preeste may seye þus ful per∣fitely in his herte ¶ I haue a tyme, lord. I knowe
wel þat alle werkis and desertis of men, be þei neuere so hooly, þei ben vnworþi for to resceyue þee, lord. So worþi. So myȝtty. So benynge. So mercyful as þou art in alle neede. ¶ A! a! soþefast merciful lord. how myche more þenne am I vnworþi þat euery day synne. and as a man vncorrigible dwelle þer-in stylle ¶ A! good lord, whi do I suche dispite to þee. to caste acknowledging his vileness; þee my lord god so preciouse in-to so foule a pitte of my concience, For soþely my sweete and graciouse souereyne lord. I knoweleche to þe þat þer nys no goonge more stynkynge þenne my soule is. ¶ A! lord, lord, þat art so humble. and so meke. what schal I do wiþ þee, kyndely lord, whi, what schal I leye þee lord in þat foule place, soþely lord I durste not. but þat I [fol. 225] hope to þi mercy ¶ But souereyne myȝtteful lord, I trowe þat þi mercy is eendeles more þenne alle myn but trusting in the mercy of Christ, orible and foule wrecchid synne, þerfore I am al trist∣ynge in þi goodnesse, merciful lord. ¶ I aventure me to resceyue þee, swete lord, as a syke man resseyueþ a medcyne. ¶ þou art a sooþfaste leche, lord, and soþely who is the true physician. I am syke. þerfore I take þee. for to be maad hool þorouȝ þee. ¶ And þe syker þat I am, by so myche I wolde ben maad hool bi þee, my swete lord; and þe more nede þat I haue of þee, þe more ententely and bisili schulde I þenke to calle vp-on þee ¶ For whi lord in helynge of my deedly sykenesse schal wel be schewyd and commendyd þe michilheed of þi goodnesse.

¶ And þenne aftir þis whenne he haþ resceyued þat Thoughts after receiving, as to the vanity of the world; myȝtteful and blessydful sacramente he may þenne þenke þus ¶ I wole not now aftir þis moste worþi mete. fede me wiþ myche of þe wordely vanite / nouþir I wole not aftir suche goostely sauoure delyte me fleischely in eny creature. ¶ Neuereþeles if it be so. þat a man feele not goostely affeccioun. ne ȝit in de∣uoute sterynge þorouȝ goostely encentynge of herte in or when there has been an absence of spiritual affec∣tions. tyme of his resseyuynge. it is good þat he þenke þenne.
þat it is a tokene of greet sykenesse of synne. or ellis of greet deeþ. or ellis it is suffraunce of god for to meke a man. ¶ But a man schal euere conceyue in his owne A man should always recognize his short comings, concience. þat he is continuelly in defaute aȝen þat myȝtteful lord and þerfore schulde he ful mekely. and obeschauntely seye to hym þus. ¶ A! lord, lord, now ful mercyful lord, what schal I do. I haue putte fyre in my bosum, and I feele noon heete of it. ¶ Lo! lo! lord euereful mercyful to [fol. 225 b.] synneful wrecchis. And whan the preste gothe to the lauatori, The Rincing. (Page 54, l. 576)
Takeytħe it in no veyn glorye;
But thanke god with ałł thy myght,

Owyr lady and her sonne dere,

Take ensampyłł of swyche blode, Take them for example, and not ignorant de∣pravers of the sacrament,

I dar wełł say that pryd gothe beforen,

Ȝif Enemys com to any coste,

Schameles and brethelis—(that nowt thee

God that mad more and lasse,

HEADNOTE.P: Next I give the opening of Lydgate's "Virtutes Missarum" from the Harleian MS. 3954, fol. 76, col. 2, which, notwithstand∣ing the similarity of name, is not to be confounded with his "Vertue of the Masse," above, p. 163.

Q.P: "Augustinus in libro de ciuitate, de vij virtutibus missarum. illo die quo videtur corpus Christi, victus necessarius tribuitur. ignorata iuramenta delentur · leuia colloquia dimittun∣tur · lumen oculorum confortatur · morte subitania non moritur · et si quis subito decesserit, pro communicatione habetur.

DIV2.L: "LOrdyngis dygne an dere, Listen, Lords, and hear of a medicine that can save from hell.
Lystyn & ȝe may here:
I wyl ȝou shywyn a medicyne,
þat xal ȝou sauyn fro helle pynne,
ȝyf ȝe it vnderstonde aryth,
ȝe xul wel plecyn god al-myth.
Seynt austyn in hys boke tellys, St Austin is cited as saying,
Quat man þat in erthe duellys,
And here a masse with god wyl
Qwat mede longyt þer tyl. that a mass heard by one shriven of sin,
Quat man be clene out of synne
And here a masse quan it be gyne,
He xal hys fode [enjoy] þat day ensures sufficient food,
Suffesantly I dar wel say.
And thour þe virtu of þe masse, freedom from oaths lightly sworn, and forgiveness of idle words,
Lyth othys suoryn xul fro hym passe;
Idel wordis xul gon a-way
And be for-ȝouyn I dar wel say.
þe syth of hys eyn gryȝe
Xal be confortyd, I ȝou seyȝe: strengthening of the eyes,
ȝyf he se þis body in bred,
It xal hym saue fro sodeyn ded;
And ȝyf he happe þat day to deyȝe, and viaticum in case of sudden death.
He stant for houselyd, I ȝow seye.
þis wytnessyt seynt austyn
And ledgyt hem in latyn. Witness St Austin and Lydgate.
Xij vertuwys þere be mo
I xal hem tellyn or I goo."

HEADNOTE.P: The twelve virtues follow. I add the third and sixth, as they are not often met with, and the sixth is a further example of apostolical authority being claimed. The eighth is given, post, p. 371.

Q.P: "Gregorius · tercia virtus est quicquid comedit in die magis conuenit nature sue post audicionem misse quam ante.

DIV2.L: "Sen gregory, þe good man,
The iij scyl telle can.
Quat man here messe or he dyne,
It is a good medycyne;
Hys mete xal han þe more fysoun
Afterward be resoun."

Q.P: "Paulus" vjta. virtus est mulier pregnans que interest misse deuota · si parit illo die · puerum parit sine magno dolore & sine dampne.

DIV2.L: "Sen poule seyt quat woman with chylde
Here a masse with herte mylde
And happe to chylde þat day
Here neythyr Neither of them. xal han no gret fray
And þe moder þe soþe to seyne
She xal han þe lesse peyne
And þis is þe vj scyl
To heryn messe with good wyl."

HEADNOTE.P: The medicinal effect which is vouched by St Gregory (III Virtus) appears under the name of St Ambrose in the Dicta Sanctorum, the opening lines of which are quoted, p. 370.

DIV2.L: "Seynt Ambrose doctour · whyche Affermyd was
Oone of the foure · seythe As I shalle the telle
A man that ete or drynkethe · Aftyr mas
The mete or drynke dygestythe Alle so welle
And to hys body · As trewe as gospelle
Profytythe more · then̄ be fore mas to ete

HEADNOTE.P: The case of the woman with child, which appears above under the name of St Paul, in these Dicta is assigned to St Chrysostom.

Q.P: "Iohannes Crisostomus · Si contigerit nulierem (mulierem) parere die illa qua missam / Audierit Absque dolore magno pariet. /

DIV2.L: "Ioħn Crisostom · Doctoure of gret renowne,
Seythe yif hyt be so þat ony womane
Wythe child · to be delyuered were bowne
That day she here mas · yf hyt plese god whane
The chyld shalle be borne · wythe oute sorow thane.
Grete to þe pregnaunt · thys is a gret grace
Now here thy mas whyls þou hast tyme and space." Rawlinson MS. Poetry, 36, fol. 7.

HEADNOTE.P: The same collection also professes to give the Latin of St Austin as to the remission of the "light oaths" (perjury) and "idle words" of Lydgate (above, p. 367); and as to hearing mass standing a man instead of being houseled, or taking his "rights."

DIV2.L: "Austyne þe famous doctour excelent.
Remembrythe the syghte · of Crystys bodye
That day hyt is sene · thy syghte verament
Conseruyd is · As lokynge wythe thyne Ie
An Alle veyne othes · pleyes and periurye.
Or vnknowyne synnes · relesyd bene they
Here mas · and þou mayst not mysspede in feye."

DIV2.L: "The same Austyne seythe · As ye may heer se
A mas deuoutly herd · be eny man̄
That same day · no sodene dethe shalle haue he
And yif he dye · wythe owte hys rygħtys than̄
For hys howselle hyt is had · As I can̄.
Shewe you be wrytyng · As thys doctour wryte

Therfor here mas · and therto þou delyte." Ib. fol. 8. In a Latin catena, "De virtutibus missae" (Bodl. MS. 832, fol. 168, b), the Latin of St Augustine is given in another form, but I need hardly say that the reader will search the "De Civitate" in vain for anything to justify it.

HEADNOTE.P: Lydgate's Vertue of the Mass (above, p. 167) ends with fifteen stanzas, which are rubricated "The vertu of heryng of Masse after seynt Bernard," the several virtues being of the same character as those in the pieces above quoted, except that here he does not assign them in the same ad libitum fashion to inspired or patristic authority. There is no occasion to multiply quotations, but I add one stanza because I do not remember to have met elsewhere with a similar appeal to the sailor's desire for a fair wind.
